title: Definition:
content:
Depression is one of the common mental disorders affecting one in four individuals in life. People with depressive disorders have considerable difficulty with daily functioning in personal, family, social, educational, occupational or other areas.
Cause of depression
Various theories for etiology exist, psychosocial stressors trigger certain physiological and chemical changes

title: Genetics
content:
Most recent research focuses on neurochemical and biological imbalances (e.g. serotonin and norepinephrine)
Psychodynamic theory (e. g. bereavement)
Psychosocial Factors (Stress, stressful life even)
Physical illnesses such as cancer, heart problems, respiratory disease
Treatments like Steroids and other medicines
Substance use (drinking alcohol regularly)
Without a clear cause.
How do you know depressive disorder?
Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5)
The DSM-5 defines Major Depressive Disorder as a condition characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a loss of interest or pleasure in most activities.
A. Five (or more) of the following symptoms must be present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning. At least one of the symptoms must be (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day (feels sad, empty, hopeless; or observed by others as tearful).
Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
Significant weight loss when not dieting, weight gain, or decrease/increase in appetite nearly every day.
Insomnia or hypersomnia (excessive sleeping) nearly every day.
Psychomotor agitation or retardation (restlessness or slowed movements) nearly every day, observed by others.
Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive/inappropriate guilt (which may be delusional) nearly every day.
Difficulty concentrating or indecisiveness nearly every day.
Recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or plan for committing suicide.
B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.
D. The occurrence is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified/unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.
E. There has never been a manic or hypomanic episode, which would indicate bipolar disorder instead.
Treatment options for MDD

title: Medications:
content:
Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) – e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline, escitalopram.
Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs) – e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine.
Atypical antidepressants – e.g., bupropion, mirtazapine.
Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) & Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs) – Used in resistant cases.

title: Psychotherapy:
content:
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) – Helps change negative thinking patterns.
Interpersonal Therapy (IPT) – Focuses on relationships and life transitions.

title: Lifestyle Changes:
content:
Regular physical activity, social support, mindfulness, and sleep regulation.
Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT):
Used for severe, treatment-resistant depression.

title: Postnatal Depression
content:
Definition:
Postnatal depression (also called postpartum depression) is a type of depression that affects parents after childbirth, most commonly occurs during pregnancy or within four weeks after childbirth. It is more severe and long-lasting than the "baby blues," which typically resolve within a few days after delivery. However, for about 10 percent of mothers, this sadness turns into a disorder known as postnatal depression.
Postnatal depression is a serious but treatable condition. Early recognition and support are crucial for recovery. If left untreated, it can affect both the parent and the child’s well-being.
